boardgame.name: Dragons
boardgame.description:
Dragons, a new version of Papillons, is a card game in which each player has a secret objective: to align four Dragons of a given color or of a given type.

Players take turns placing a card on the table, trying to obtain their secret flying alignment or to move an already placed card to another place. They also have two tokens which can be used only once: one token removes an already placed card from the game, and the other one fixes an already placed card so that it cannot be moved during the game.

There are versions for two players, and a cooperative one for 4 players playing in pairs.

boardgame.name: Capitalism, USA
boardgame.description:
Each quarter our fair city accepts four applicants to become part of our citizenry. These applicants will be given all the same connections and resources to prove to the leaders of our city that they are worthy to become one with the populous. Five hundred members of a random workforce and the ability to produce goods and services from different aspects of business. It is their goal to be as profitable as possible and succeed in creating a workforce that is focused solely on profit. There will be troubles along the way, from political insiders, government interference, and those seeking social justice. Our city is one of peace and profit driven by money and power. Are you worthy to be part of our community?
Welcome... to Capitalism USA.

Players are all billionaire industrialists that are taking on a new business in Capitalism USA, seeking residence, it is your goal to obtain the most money before one player reaches a completely their full potential of Profit and Progress. Each player is given five Workforce cards, these are laid in front of each player face up. displaying a human workforce residing in Capitalism, USA. As the game progresses they will become an automated workforce that is more profitable for you the billionaire.

Each player is dealt FIVE Workforce cards, these will represent your workers of your new company. Place them face up, showing the occupation, in front of you for the remainder of the game.

The game ends once a player has flipped all FIVE Workforce cards to Profit and Progress. The player with the most money is the winner.

boardgame.name: Hero Realms
Hero Realms: Jeu de Deckbuilding
Битвы героев
boardgame.description:
Hero Realms is a fantasy-themed deck-building game that is an adaptation of the award-winning Star Realms game. The game includes basic rules for two-player games, along with rules for multiplayer formats such as Free-For-All, Hunter, and Hydra.

Each player starts the game with a ten-card personal deck containing gold (for buying) and weapons (for combat). You start each turn with a new hand of five cards from your personal deck. When your deck runs out of cards, you shuffle your discard pile into your new deck. An 80-card Market deck is shared by all players, with five cards being revealed from that deck to create the Market Row. As you play, you use gold to buy champion cards and action cards from the Market. These champions and actions can generate large amounts of gold, combat, or other powerful effects. You use combat to attack your opponent and their champions. When you reduce your opponent's score (called health) to zero, you win!

Multiple expansions are available for Hero Realms that allow players to start as a particular character (Cleric, Fighter, Ranger, Thief, or Wizard) and fight cooperatively against a Boss, fight Boss decks against one another, or compete in a campaign mode that has you gain experience to work through different levels of missions.

boardgame.description:
User summary:

A small deck of custom cards is used in play to determine the length of life of characters. The cards are provided as print-and-play components, but could easily be created by hand on slips of paper. The game follows set phases but there otherwise are few rules.

boardgame.name: Wicked Words! (Vol 2, Issue 10 - Nov 2015)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

First, we have an essay I wrote called “No Dice.” If you heard
the Big Announcement recently, know that they’re linked. That’s
all I’m saying for now.

Second, we have Part 2 of The Great and Terrible Life of Shara
Yvarai. This ends Act 1. And it ends with a bit of a cliffhanger.

Then we have Blood: A Game about Vampires. It’s a game that
uses the same system as Secret, so you can play the two
together. Yeah, that’s intentional. Expect three more games in
the same vein. Hah! Vein! See what I did there? Yeah? Okay. Never mind.

Next is a tiny game called Homeless Angels. I’ll let that one
speak for itself.

And finally, we have Part 1 of a game called Honor Among
Thieves. This is the setting chapter. Mechanics chapter next.
